resources.string: Connection timed out - BBS not available
SSH not available - cryptlib not built
Are you sure you want to delete %1$s?

Terminal Controls

Special Keys Toolbar
The toolbar at the bottom provides:
• CTL - Control key modifier
• ESC - Escape key
• DEL - Backspace/Delete
• TAB - Tab key
• ENT - Enter/Return
• ▲▼◀▶ - Arrow keys
• ⋮ - Menu

Zoom
• Pinch with two fingers to zoom
• Double-tap to reset zoom

Pan/Scroll
When zoomed past 100%, drag with one finger to pan.

Scrollback History
• Volume Up to scroll back in history
• Volume Down to scroll toward live
• Tap or type to return to live view

Screen Always On
Screen stays on while connected.

Keyboard
Tap the terminal to show keyboard.

Clickable URLs
Tap URLs on screen to open in browser.

Show Cursor
Toggle from the ⋮ menu.

Snapshot
Capture screenshot for thumbnail:
• Tap ⋮ menu → "Snapshot"
• Image shows in your BBS list

Connection Status Bar
Shows duration, screen mode, data stats.
Can be toggled per-connection in the Phonebook entry.

Session Logging

Capture Session Transcript
• Tap ⋮ menu → "Start Logging"
• Red "LOG" indicator appears
• Tap ⋮ → "Stop Logging" when done
• Logs saved with BBS name and timestamp

File Transfer (ZMODEM)

Auto-Detection
• Downloads start automatically when BBS sends
• Uploads prompt you to pick a file when BBS requests

Send File
• Start ZMODEM receive on BBS first
• App will prompt you to select a file
• Or tap ⋮ → "Send File" to pre-queue

Receive File
• Usually auto-detected
• Or tap ⋮ → "Receive File (ZMODEM)"
• Saves to download folder

SSH Connections

SSH Credentials
• Passwords are encrypted using Android Keystore
• Passwords are NOT exported with your BBS list
• When editing, leave password empty to keep existing

Home Screen

Quick Connect Buttons
Two customizable buttons for instant connection to your favorite BBSes.

Setting Quick Connect
Tap an empty Quick Connect button to choose a BBS from your Phonebook.

Clearing Quick Connect
Long-press an assigned Quick Connect button to clear it.

Phonebook

Reorder
Long-press and drag to reorder.

Edit/Delete
Tap connection to view details or delete.

Thumbnails
Tap thumbnail to view full-size image.

Settings

Access from ⋮ menu on main screen:

Bell & Notifications
• Toggle sounds and vibration
• Choose bell tone

Display
• Screen orientation lock

Data Management
• Download folder
• Export/Import BBS list

Home Screen Widget

Quick Connect Widget
• Long-press home screen → Widgets
• Find TERMinator, drag to home
• Select BBS connection
• Tap widget to instantly connect

Version 1.1.4

• Added 4 new default BBSes with snapshots
• New defaults auto-added for existing users
• Fixed phonebook order lost when adding entries
• Fixed snapshots not refreshing in phonebook

Version 1.1.3

• Added TelnetS (Telnet over SSL) support
• Fixed virtual keyboard Enter key on some devices

Version 1.1.2

• Added scrollback using volume keys

Version 1.1.1

• Initial release

TERMinator - BBS Terminal
Version 1.1.4

Based on SyncTERM 1.8b
Copyright © 2007 Stephen Hurd
Licensed under GNU GPL v2

SSH support via cryptlib (Synchronet)
Copyright © 1992-2023 Peter Gutmann
Dual licensed: Sleepycat/GPL-compatible

Android version by JSONBourne 2026
JSONBourne Innovations
jsonbourneinnovations@gmail.com
deadmodemsociety.com

Source code:
https://github.com/omniphil/TERMinator-Android

Special thx to aNACHRONiST (aNSt) for the artwork and testing!
Must be connected to transfer files
%1$s queued for upload. Start upload on BBS to begin transfer.
A file is already queued for upload
BBS is ready to receive a file. Select a file to upload.
Must be connected to log session
Please select a folder where downloaded files will be saved. This ensures your files are kept in a permanent location.
This will replace your existing %1$d connections with %2$d connections from the file. Continue?

>>> You\'re looking at a fresh zero day drop from JSONBourne <<< TERMinator, a fresh new BBS terminal app for people who live their life 64K at a time. Greetings to all the crews still pushing pixels in 16 colors, all the SysOps who never sleep, and anyone still rocking a 1084S monitor like it\'s 1989. Special thx to aNACHRONiST (aNSt) for providing his excellent skillz and for making textmode look like pixel CG! If this thing breaks, you get to keep both pieces. Send fixes, not complaints. >>> end of line <<<

string-array.name: computing_history_facts
string-array.item: 1945: ENIAC, the first general-purpose electronic computer, is completed
1947: The transistor is invented at Bell Labs
1958: Jack Kilby demonstrates the first integrated circuit
1964: BASIC programming language is created at Dartmouth
1965: Gordon Moore predicts transistor doubling every two years
1968: Douglas Engelbart demos the mouse, hypertext, and video conferencing
1969: ARPANET sends its first message from UCLA to Stanford
1970: UNIX is created at Bell Labs
1971: Intel releases the 4004, the first commercial microprocessor
1972: The C programming language is developed at Bell Labs
1973: Xerox Alto becomes the first computer with a graphical user interface
1974: Vint Cerf and Bob Kahn develop the TCP/IP protocol
1975: The Altair 8800 launches the personal computer revolution
1976: Steve Wozniak builds the Apple I in a garage
1977: The Apple II, TRS-80, and Commodore PET debut
1978: The first BBS goes online in Chicago
1979: VisiCalc launches, the killer app that sold Apple IIs
1981: IBM PC released with 16KB RAM and no hard drive
1981: The Osborne 1 becomes the first portable computer
1982: The Commodore 64 launches, selling 17 million units
1982: Time magazine names the computer \"Machine of the Year\"
1983: TCP/IP becomes the standard protocol for ARPANET
1984: Apple Macintosh debuts with legendary Super Bowl ad
1985: Commodore Amiga 1000 brings multimedia to home computing
1986: Intel releases the 386 processor at 16 MHz
1987: The Amiga 500 becomes the best-selling Amiga ever
1987: IBM PS/2 introduces the VGA graphics standard
1987: GIF image format is introduced by CompuServe
1988: MS-DOS 4.0 adds support for hard drives over 32MB
1990: The World Wide Web goes live on Christmas Day
1991: Linus Torvalds releases the first Linux kernel
1993: Mosaic browser brings the web to the masses
FidoNet at its peak connects over 35,000 BBS systems
A 1200 baud modem could transfer 1MB in about 2 hours
The C64 had more computing power than the Apollo 11
The Amiga could display 4,096 colors when PCs had 16
Early hard drives cost about $100,000 per gigabyte
ANSI art became the dominant art form on BBS systems
The sound of a modem connecting was music to our ears
Door games like Legend of the Red Dragon defined BBS gaming
SysOps were the unsung heroes of the early online world
CBBS, the first BBS, was created by Ward Christensen in 1978
TradeWars 2002 was one of the most popular BBS door games
The XMODEM protocol revolutionized file transfers on BBSes
ZMODEM became the gold standard for BBS file transfers
FidoNet used store-and-forward to relay mail between BBSes
The term \"shareware\" was coined in the BBS era
BBSes pioneered online communities before the internet
The \"elite\" BBS scene used leet speak long before the internet
Calling long distance to reach a BBS could cost a fortune
BBS door games ran as external programs launched by the BBS
File ratios required uploading to earn download credits
ANSI bombs could crash terminals with malicious escape codes
The demoscene grew from the BBS warez scene
QWK packets let users read BBS messages offline
Blueboxing and phreaking were closely tied to BBS culture
Many BBSes had only one phone line - busy signals were common
14.4k modems were blazing fast in the early 90s
28.8k and 56k modems arrived just as BBSes began to fade
Echomail let BBSes share message forums across FidoNet
NetMail was FidoNet\'s version of email between systems
Many SysOps ran BBSes from their bedrooms as teenagers
Some BBSes are still running today on Telnet
1979: Hayes introduces the Smartmodem with AT commands
1980: Usenet launches, connecting universities via UUCP
1983: CompuServe introduces CB Simulator, early chat rooms
1984: FidoNet is created by Tom Jennings in San Francisco
1985: Quantum Link launches, later becoming AOL
1986: LISTSERV creates the first email mailing lists
1988: IRC (Internet Relay Chat) is created in Finland
The Hayes AT command set became the industry standard
2400 baud modems made real-time chat practical on BBSes
V.32bis modems brought 14.4 kbps speeds in 1991
V.34 modems reached 28.8 kbps, then 33.6 kbps
V.90 and V.92 achieved 56 kbps - the analog limit
Prodigy, CompuServe, and GEnie were early online services
The Source was one of the first consumer online services
Synchronet BBS software is still actively developed today
Mystic BBS keeps the BBS tradition alive on modern systems
The FOSSIL driver standardized serial port access for BBSes
YMODEM added batch file transfers to XMODEM
Kermit protocol was popular on mainframes and minicomputers
BiModem allowed simultaneous chat and file transfers
HSLink could transfer files in both directions at once
The Telnet protocol gave BBSes new life on the internet
SSH connections now secure modern BBS communications
SyncTERM keeps classic terminal emulation alive today
Zone 1 was North America in FidoNet addressing
A FidoNet address looked like 1:123/456.7
Points were users who picked up mail from a BBS node

resources.string: No BBS assigned. Long-press to select a BBS.

Quick connect to your favorite BBS (1 slot)
Quick connect widget with 2 BBS slots
Quick connect widget with 3 BBS slots
Tap a BBS to create a quick-connect widget
No saved connections. Add a BBS first.
Tap a BBS to assign to each slot
Shows when connected to a BBS to keep the connection alive
Play a sound when BBS sends a bell tone
Vibrate when BBS sends a bell tone

string-array.name: bell_sound_descriptions
string-array.item: No Speaker (RF Interference) • Front panel music via CPU noise on AM radio
1-bit Speaker Toggle • Two-tone sequence (880Hz → 440Hz), high-low pattern
MOS 6522 VIA + Piezo • Simple beeper, very short clicky tick with fast decay
Cassette Port Audio • Buzzy square wave at 450Hz with frequency wobble
DC305 Bell Generator • The canonical terminal bell, clean 750Hz tone
POKEY C012294 Chip • Mixed frequencies with buzzy complex character
MOS 6522 VIA + 6-bit DAC • Business computer, slightly different than Apple II
MOS 6560/6561 VIC Chip • 3 square wave voices, simpler predecessor to SID
Motorola MC6847 + 6-bit DAC • Direct digital audio, unique character
Intel 8253 PIT + PC Speaker • Square wave at 1000Hz, the harsh iconic beep
Texas Instruments SN76489 • Descending frequency sweep (2000Hz → 800Hz)
Ferranti ULA + Piezo • Ultra-simple 1-bit toggle, more primitive than Spectrum
TMS9919 PSG Chip • Distinctive warble/vibrato effect with two voices
Piezo Speaker • First portable computer, high-pitched 2kHz tinny with ringing
MOS 6581/8580 SID Chip • Pulse wave with modulating duty cycle, warm and rich
Ferranti ULA Beeper (1-bit) • Rapid pitch bend, starts high, drops, stabilizes
Piezo Beeper • Popular CP/M portable, clean business-like square wave
Texas Instruments SN76489 • Game console style, descending arpeggio
Ricoh 2A03 APU • Triangle wave bass + 25% duty pulse, warm NES sound
General Instrument AY-3-8910 • Quick descending two-note, Japanese standard
Apple Sound Chip (ASC) • Chorused 480Hz with additive synthesis
General Instrument AY-3-8912 • Quick 3-note arpeggio, bright and punchy
Texas Instruments SN76496 (3-voice) • C major chord, richer than PC speaker
Texas Instruments SN76496 (3-voice) • Two voices in octave, PCjr home style
MOS 8364 Paula (4-channel) • Warm 8-bit PCM with harmonics, stereo output
VIDC1 (8-channel PCM) • Wavetable-style harmonic-rich bell timbre
Motorola DSP56001 + DAC • FM synthesis, sophisticated curved envelope
Sharp LR35902 APU (4-ch) • Pulse wave with duty sweep, 4-bit DAC
AMD AM79C30A Codec • Clean Unix beep, pure 440Hz sine, professional
Uses your device\'s default notification sound
